description.narrative: Miljöministeriet har efterfrågat ett stöd på 1,462 478€ (15 MSEK) under 29 månader för att stärka Serbiska industrins och myndigheternas tillämpning av EUs Industrial Emissions Directive, (IED) industriutsläppsbestämmelser. Ministeriet har föreslagit att Cleaner Production Centre Serbia (CPCS) vid Belgrad Universitet genomför projektet. Målsättningen är att öka industrins miljöansvar i enlighet med principen om att ”förorenaren betalar” (Polluter Pay Principle, PPP). Projektet kommer även att bistå myndigheterna med ansvar för tillsyn och övervakning att i samarbete med företag utarbeta, riktlinjer, mallar, checklistor manualer, och föreslå tillämpningsföreskrifter för hur kontroll och tillståndsprövning ska genomföras för att få bedriva verksamhet. Efter regeringsombildningen 2017 tillkom ett miljöministerium vilket kan ses som en politisk markering om att miljöfrågan kommer att prioriteras. En revidering av regelverket (Gazette No 135/04, IPPC) och/eller tillämpningsföreskrifterna krävs för att anpassa sig till EUs industriutsläppsbestämmelser (IED), vilket nu är planerat till 2018. Att det dröjt är ett tecken på den tidigare regeringens lägre prioritering av miljöfrågan, men Sida bedömer att detta inte är avgörande för att genomföra projektet. Sida bedömer att den privata matindustrin kommer att följa EUs IED för att kunna exportera till EU, även om regelverket inte har formaliserats av regeringen. För tung industri kan det krävas en genomgripande strukturomvandling innan de lever upp till EUs miljökrav. EUs industri-utsläppsbestämmelser anger att bäst tillgängliga teknik (Best Available Technology) BAT ska användas och att det är industrins sammantagna integrerade miljöeffekt som ska bedömmas. Vid prövning av integrerade tillstånd beaktar man förutom utsläppsnivåer (vatten luft och mark) och buller även hela verksamhetens energi- och resurs effektivitet. EUs IED innebär även att Serbiska företag behöver öka sin transparens och allmänhetens insyn. Sida bedömer att projektet har förutsättningar att ge effekter som är ekonomiskt, ekologiskt och sociologiskt hållbara. Projektet är en fortsättning på ett projekt som genomfördes av CPCS 2015-2017 där Serbiens 94 kyckling- och fläskproduktions (djurstallar) anläggningar kartlades och 10 anläggningar har skickat in sina planer (Directive Specific Implementation Plans) DSIP. I detta projekt är fokus på matproduktionen (slakterier, mejerier, framställning av matolja, socker, öl och soja). Under 2015 kartlades samtliga Serbiens 224 industriella anläggningar där det krävs DSIP och projektet kommer även att göra en uppdatering av DSIP för alla industrisektorer eller 224 anläggningar där det krävs IPPC tillstånd.

The Ministry of the Environment has requested a support of 1,462 478€ (15 MSEK) for 27 månader months to strengthen the application of the EU's Industrial Emissions Directive (IED) by the Serbian industry and authorities. The Ministry has proposed that Cleaner Production Center Serbia (CPCS) at Belgrade University implement the project. The goal is to increase the environmental responsibility of industry in accordance with the "Polluter Pay Principle, PPP" principle. The project will also assist the supervisory authorities to develop, guidelines, templates, checklists manuals, in cooperation with enterprises, and propose by-laws for inspection. Effective implementation of the project requires revision of the regulatory and implementing rules of the current EU IED, which is now scheduled for 2018. It is a sign of the previous government's prioritization of environmental responsibility, but Sida considers that this is not crucial for carrying out the project. Sida believes that the private industry will follow the EU IED to export to the EU, although it is not a formal requirement by the Serbian government. There are industries where it is not economically profitable to invest in accordance with the EU's IED and which may shutdown, but at the same time, the introduction of the EU standard will bring about 5800 jobs to be innovated and / or retained in the food industry if Serbia complies with the EU environmental standard, in part to resulting from increased exports to the EU. However, this structural change means that the new jobs often require different skills than those closed down. The EU's IED state that Best Available Technology (BAT) is to be used and that it is the industry's overall integrated environmental impact to be assessed. In examining integrated conditions, consideration is also given to emission levels (water air and land) and noise, as well as the energy and resource efficiency of the entire operation's. The EU IED also require that Serbian companies need to increase their transparency and public transparency. Companies are expected to have a strong interest in improving their "environmental performance" as many want to export their products to the EU. Sida believes that the development effort has the potential to produce economically, ecologically and sociologically sustainable effects. The project is a continuation of a project conducted by CPCS 2015-2017, where Serbia's 94 chicken and pork production facilities were mapped and 10 plants have submitted their plans Directive Specific Implementation Plans DSIP). In this IED project focuses on food production (slaughterhouses, dairies, cooking oil, sugar, beer and soy). In 2015, all of Serbia's 224 industrial facilities were mapped where DSIP is required and the project will also update if DSIP has been followed by other industry sectors.

The general objective is to support the Serbian authorities and a selection of companies (operators) in the food production chain in the implementation of the EU Industrial Emission Directive (IED), in order to foster technological improvement and reduce the impact on the environment (i.e air, water, energy efficiency). Specific components are: 1) Supporting the preparation of Negotiation Position for Chapter 27. Sweden and Serbia cooperate on EU environmental reform in Serbia, the environmental and climate Chapter 27. Under the first component support prepared the legislative framework in Serbia implementing the EU Industrial Emission Directive (IED). 2) Technical support to companies and competent authorities involved in the process of issuance and control of integrated permits for installations in the food sector. 3) Promotion of technological improvement in the food production chain. Promoting economic integration with the EU and development of market economy and develop innovative market opportunities. 4) Awareness and capacity building through education and events. The project is implemented by the Cleaner Production Center at the Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy (Belgrade University), in cooperation with the Serbian Ministry of Environmental Protection.

description.narrative: The overall assessment is that the contribution has well achieved the objectives of the intervention and created short and long term results. The contribution has strengthened the capacity of the Government and Ministry of Environmental protection on EU environmental industrial policy reform, and contributed to building capacity at local level, in companies and within the educational structure at the University of Belgrade. The intervention has also contributed in preparing the readiness for permitting procedures and investments in clean technologies. On the four components: 1) Supporting the preparation of Negotiation Position for Chapter 27 Sweden and Serbia cooperate on strengthening EU environmental reform in Serbia, including the EU legislative package on environment and climate, Chapter 27. Under the first component, support has been given to strengthen to the legislative framework in Serbia, implementing the EU Industrial Emission Directive (IED). The achieved results include: - Analysis and preparation of legislation and a Directive Specific Implementation Plan (DSIP) has been completed. This was an important contribution when Serbia's finalised its Negotiating Position on Chapter 27. The Negotiating position was submitted to the EU Commission in 2020. 2) Technical support to companies and competent authorities involved in the process of issuance and control of integrated permits for installations in the food sector. The achieved results include: - A number of municipalities and companies have been supported in permitting processes and 10 draft permits have been prepared, including a template of integrated permits for installations in food sector and training of almost 50 inspectors. - A number of permits for farms prepared, contributing to reduced environmental impact. - Best Available Technology assessments have been made, an important basis for future investments in green industry. 3) Promotion of technological improvement in the food production chain. Promoting economic integration with the EU and development of market economy and develop innovative market opportunities. The achieved results include: - Analysis and support to the preparation of several environmental investment projects in the food production chain. 4) Awareness and capacity building through education and events The achieved results include: - More than 600 participants trained at workshops. - Several trainings of inspection to improve environmental performance in businesses. - More than 130 students involved in education and trainings, including high school competitions. - Broad media activities communicating advantages with EU environmental standards in industry.
